qas.question: Under what circumstances do glaciers form?

answers.text: where the accumulation of snow and ice exceeds ablation
The area in which a glacier forms

qas.question: What shape is a cirque, generally?
How much ice and snow is minimally necessary to begin to slide on steep glaciers?
What forms were snow and ice accumulation is equal to its melting
What geological features formed by glaciers?
What happens in a minimum of 15 feet of snow?

plausible_answers.text: a combination of surface slope, gravity and pressure.

qas.question: What causes a glaciers stop moving?

context: <b4_0>Glaciers<b4_0/> form <a0_0>where the accumulation of snow and ice exceeds ablation<a0_0/>. <a1_0>The area in which a glacier forms<a1_0/> is called a <b5_0>cirque<b5_0/> (corrie or cwm) - a typically <a2_0>armchair-shaped<a2_0/> geological feature (such as a depression between mountains enclosed by arêtes) - which collects and compresses through gravity the snow which falls into it. This snow collects and is compacted by the weight of the snow falling above it forming névé. Further crushing of the individual snowflakes and squeezing the air from the snow turns it into 'glacial ice'. This glacial ice will fill the cirque until it 'overflows' through a geological weakness or vacancy, such as the gap between two mountains. When the mass of snow and ice is sufficiently thick, <b6_0>it begins to move<b6_0/> due to <b7_0>a combination of surface slope, gravity and pressure.<b7_0/> On steeper slopes, this can occur with as little as <a3_0>15 m (50 ft)<a3_0/> of snow-ice.
